text:
That’s the default of how `DateTime` objects are printed. If you’d rather transform it to a custom-formatted string column, you could do something like:
```df.dt = Dates.format.(dt.dt, "yyyy-mm-dd HH:MM:SS.s")```

elements.text: objects are printed. If you’d rather transform it to a custom-formatted string column, you could do something like:

text: Thanks I had no idea this could be formatted in a custom way like this.

text: same here, custom time formats are a nice touch!

elements.text: same here, custom time formats are a nice touch!

text: Just note that you’re changing the actual type of object you’re working with here. A `DateTime` object knows how to do “datetime” kinds of things, like `DateTime(2021, 3, 12) + Day(1)`. Once you call `Dates.format(dt, "yyyy-mm-dd HH:MM:SS.s")`, all you have is a `String`, which doesn’t know how to do “datetime” stuff.
